page.title: 09Farming_beef.
page.content: The smaller,but nevertheless important secondary side of hill farming,is the breeding and rearing of beef cattle.An average herd is about thirty five to forty cows plus one bull.Each cow will usually bear one calf every year and these are born from March to May.They are kept out of doors and suck from their mothers, as well as eat grass, during the whole of that time.In the October,following their birth,the calves,like the lambs, are taken to market, but,unlike the lambs,they do not go immediately for slaughter.Instead they are bought by farmers who live on the Cheshire Plain.They are then kept on the lowland farms where they are fattened up until they are eighteen months old, when once again they are returned to market,this time to be bought for immediate slaughter.
